awd_titl_txt: Students Understanding Chemistry Concepts to Enhance STEM Skills (SUCCESS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Students Understanding Chemistry Concepts to Enhance STEM Skills (SUCCESS) project at Jackson State University will target at-risk and underrepresented students, with a focus on biology majors, and will enable them to successfully complete general and organic chemistry. The SUCCESS project will provide three-day Chemistry Readiness Workshops prior to the start of a course, and an additional two-hour SUCCESS Session during each week of the semester. Enabling at-risk and underrepresented students to succeed in their chosen major will support diversification of the STEM workforce. How these interventions promote student success will be documented, and the knowledge gained will complement successful approaches to undergraduate instruction across multiple STEM disciplines.  

The impact of Chemistry Readiness Workshops, the modified Xavier University Chemistry Drill Program, and Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) sessions on the success of students in general chemistry will be documented. Data from the intervention groups will be compared to historical data and evaluated to determine whether these strategies: (a) improve attendance in chemistry classes, (b) decrease drop/fail/withdraw rates, (c) improve students' conceptual understanding of chemistry, and (d) improve student retention. The results will be disseminated in biology and chemistry education conferences, and associated proceedings. Overall, this project will contribute to what is known about the promoting student success in STEM with at-risk and underrepresented students. This project will support broadening participation in STEM and the STEM workforce.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal is aligned with two (2) specific objectives that reveal the effectiveness of the POGIL Instruction and Chemistry Readiness Workshops; and the improvement of biology students in each of their first four chemistry classes.

Objective 1: The improvement in the success of biology students (including other majors) from the implementation of POGIL instruction and Chemistry Readiness Workshops. The data presented as follows:

CHEM 141 Fall 2021

We implemented several digital tools into the first semester general chemistry curriculum to improve learning outcomes for the students. Cengage MindTap is a digital learning tool that integrates online homework using videos, study tools, and assessment with an ebook. We implemented MindTap assignments into the curriculum in the fall 2021 semester. The MindTap tool was implemented due to the low attendance of students attending either the face-to-face or the online supplementary instruction. A significant percentage of the students either did not complete the MindTap assignments or submitted the assignments after the due dates. The assignments required the students to read content, watch videos, and complete questions on the content read. Each section was followed by a short assessment of student learning. The students had more than one attempt for each assessment. We compared the average MindTap scores with the average exam scores for two sections of general chemistry. There was a positive correlation between the average scores on MindTap assignments and average scores on exams (Figure1).

On average, students that performed well on the MindTap assignments also performed well on course exams. The MindTap assignments appear effective to assist students with learning course content. However, an intervention is needed for students with low completion rates for the MindTap assignments.

We implemented using Nearpod as a digital tool for formative classroom assessment and student feedback during the classroom instruction. This monitored student engagement and assessed student learning in real-time. Students also responded positively to the low-stake assessment of their learning. Whole class discussions increased after the results were shown and students showed more interested in the lecture as a result. We will continue using the Nearpod for formative assessment.

An item analysis of the content on Exam 1 showed students had difficulties with calculations (Figure 2) involving unit conversion and dimensional analysis. Frequent responses for course improvement were for more time working problems in class and more emphasis on specific content to be covered on the exams. The students performed poorly on calculations involving formulas for frequency, wavelength, and energy.

Figure 2. The percent correct for content items on exam 1.

The average ACS (American Chemical Society) exam raw scores were 22.4 for the fall 2019 semester and 23.8 for the fall 2021 semester. This is significant because the students transitioned from a year of on online instruction back to face-to-face instruction and there were disruptions due to COVID-19 related issues. We believe the implementation of digital tools into the curriculum was instrumental in maintaining student’s learning outcomes.

Previous data indicated that students who scored a minimum of thirty on the ACS Toledo placement exam passed the general chemistry course with a grade of "C" or better. The lower the score on the placement exam, the more likely the student would fail the course (DWF grades). The data from the two courses are shown in Table 1. As data shows, students that score a minimum of thirty on the placement test tend to pass the general chemistry course with a grade of "C" or better regardless of their MindTap assignment scores. However, students with a score of less than thirty on the placement test and a minimum score of seventy on the MindTap assignments also passed the course with a grade of "C" or better. There was also a general trend of increasing post-test scores for students with higher MindTap scores. Our results suggest that using MindTap can increase student’s learning outcomes for students that are underprepared for general chemistry.

 


MindTap Scores Pre-Test Scores Post-Test Scores Letter Grade

96.51 14 21 B
95.1 42 A
93.67 29 40 A

*Students with a MindTap score of less than 69.5 and a placement score of less than 30 did not pass the course. There was one student that performed well on the MindTap assignments and showed little improvement on the post-test and failed the course.
